nexttext: in which the space of gauge states is denoted by $\underline{\underline{{\cal{N}}}}$. It is the subspace of the physical space $\underline{{\cal{K}}}$. It is actually orthogonal to $\underline{{\cal{K}}}$. Indeed, any physical state $\Psi \in {\cal{K}}$ is equal to its "gauge transform", $ \exp{-\frac{\pi\lambda}{H}}(a_g^\dag - a_g)\Psi$, up to an element of $\underline{\underline{{\cal{N}}}}$; two such states are said physically equivalent. On this basis, observables are determined through the property that they do not "see" the gauge states. More accurately, considering any pair of equivalent physical states, an observable $A$ is a symmetric operator on $\underline{{\cal{H}}}$ verifying $\langle\Psi|A|\Psi\rangle=\langle\Psi'|A|\Psi'\rangle$. The field operator $\varphi$, therefore, is not an observable (it is gauge dependent). Nevertheless, respecting the fact that $\mu$ refers to global coordinates, the physically interesting observables (the energy-momentum tensor for instance; see the next section) are built using operators $\partial_\mu$ on the total space \cite{de Bievre6230,Gazeau1415}. While, as usual in a Gupta-Bleuler formalism, the expectation values of observables would be evaluated only with physical states, more exactly, the elements of $\cal{K}/\cal{N}$:

nexttext:
With respect to the product (\ref{inner}), there exists a complete orthonormal set of mode solutions of Eq. (\ref{Eq}), i.e.
\begin{eqnarray} &(\phi_\alpha,\phi_{\alpha'})=\delta _{\alpha \alpha'}, \;\; (\phi_\alpha ^*,\phi_{\alpha'}^*)= -\delta _{\alpha \alpha'},& {\nonumber}\\
&(\phi_\alpha,\phi_{\alpha'}^*)= 0,& \label{eq:ortho} \end{eqnarray}
the set of $\{\phi_\alpha ,\phi_\alpha ^*\}$ are, respectively, positive and negative norm states. In the context of the Krein quantization method, as already discussed, the vacuum state and associated Fock space are constructed by expanding the field operator $\varphi$ in terms of $\{\phi_\alpha,\phi^\ast_\alpha\}$ as follows
\begin{eqnarray} &\varphi =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\varphi_+ + \varphi_-)&{\nonumber}\\
&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \Big( \sum_\alpha (a_\alpha \phi_\alpha + a^\dagger_\alpha \phi^*_\alpha) + \sum_\alpha (b^\dagger_\alpha \phi_\alpha + b_\alpha \phi^*_\alpha) \Big).& \;\;\label{fo-frw} \end{eqnarray}
The subscripts $"+"$ and $"-"$ are, respectively, referred to physical and non-physical parts of the field operator. $a_\alpha |0\rangle=0$ and $b_\alpha |0\rangle=0$ determine the Fock vacuum state $|0\rangle$, while $a_\alpha ^\dag |0\rangle=|1_\alpha \rangle$ and $b_\alpha ^\dag |0\rangle= |\bar 1_\alpha \rangle$ are the physical and non-physical one-particle states. Note that, $[a_\alpha, a^\dagger_{\alpha'}] = \delta_{\alpha \alpha'},\; [b_\alpha, b^\dagger_{\alpha'}] = -\delta_{\alpha \alpha'}$ and the other commutation relations are zero.

Now, let us focus on the energy-momentum tensor $T_{ij}$. As discussed before, in this context as usual in a Gupta-Bleuler formalism, the expectation values of the energy-momentum tensor, as an observable, will be evaluated only with physical states $|\vec{\alpha}\rangle$.\footnote{$|\vec{\alpha}\rangle\equiv|{\alpha}_1^{n_1}...{\alpha}_l^{n_l}\rangle = \frac{1}{\sqrt{n_1!...n_l!}}(a_{\alpha_1}^\dag)^{n_1}...(a_{\alpha_l}^\dag)^{n_l}|0\rangle.$} In this regard, the starting point generally is
\begin{eqnarray} \langle \vec{\alpha}|\partial_i\varphi(x)\partial_j\varphi(x)|\vec{\alpha}\rangle = \sum_l \partial_i\phi_\alpha (x)\partial_j\phi_\alpha ^\ast(x)\hspace{1.5cm}{\nonumber}\\
- \partial_i\phi_\alpha ^\ast(x)\partial_j\phi_\alpha (x) + 2 \sum_l n_l \Re \Big(\partial_i\phi_{\alpha_l}^\ast(x)\partial_j\phi_{\alpha_l}(x)\Big). \end{eqnarray}
Analogous to the usual QFT, the first term on the right brings about the appearance of infinite divergences in the theory. However, the unusual presence of the second term with the minus sign (corresponding to the terms of the field containing $b_\alpha$ and $b_\alpha ^\dag$) automatically removes divergences and hence there is an automatic renormalization of the $T_{ij}$'s (no infinite term appears). So, we obtain

nexttext:
Following the similar manner for the other canonically quantizable theories; substituting the various fields $\chi$ (for interacting terms) by their restricted forms $\Pi_+^\chi \chi \Pi_+^\chi$ ($\Pi_+^\chi$ refers to the corresponding projector), the unitarity of the theory would be assured, while the so-called radiative corrections would be the same as the usual quantum field theory \cite{Garidi}. The vanishing VEV of the energy-momentum tensor is indeed the only difference between such a Krein field theory and the usual ones (at least in the Minkowskian limit). [To obtain detailed discussions about the unitarity condition and compatibility with (Hilbert space) QFT's counterpart in the Minkowskian limit, one could refer to Ref. \cite{Garidi}).]
